pullRequest.body:
Adds theorems for showing that several compositions of a bilinear map with another linear map is injective, surjective, or bijective.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

nodes.body:
### PR summary [c9716f043f](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/21491/commits/c9716f043f3928823f673dd8d4156d334d388486)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ bijective_compr₂_of_equiv`
`+ injective_compr₂_of_injective`
`+ surjective_compr₂_of_equiv`
`+ surjective_compr₂_of_exists_rightInverse`
`+ surjective_linearMapComp_left_of_exists_rightInverse`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

Very nice: this has converged into exactly the right form.

I suggest adding the following just below `LinearMap.exists_rightInverse_of_surjective` in the file `Mathlib/Algebra/Module/Projective.lean`:
```lean
open Function in
theorem _root_.LinearMap.surjective_linearMapComp_left_of_surjective [Projective R P]
    {f : M →ₗ[R] P} (hf_surj : Surjective f) : Surjective (fun g : N →ₗ[R] M ↦ f.comp g) :=
  surjective_linearMapComp_left_of_exists_rightInverse <|
    f.exists_rightInverse_of_surjective <| range_eq_top_of_surjective f hf_surj
```

Thanks!

bors d+

:v: morrison-daniel can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).

> Very nice: this has converged into exactly the right form.
> 
> I suggest adding the following just below `LinearMap.exists_rightInverse_of_surjective` in the file `Mathlib/Algebra/Module/Projective.lean`:
> 
> ```lean
> open Function in
> theorem _root_.LinearMap.surjective_linearMapComp_left_of_surjective [Projective R P]
>     {f : M →ₗ[R] P} (hf_surj : Surjective f) : Surjective (fun g : N →ₗ[R] M ↦ f.comp g) :=
>   surjective_linearMapComp_left_of_exists_rightInverse <|
>     f.exists_rightInverse_of_surjective <| range_eq_top_of_surjective f hf_surj
> ```
> 
> Thanks!
> 
> bors d+

Should this instead be called the following?
```lean
theorem _root_.Function.Surjective.surjective_linearMapComp_left ...
```

Thanks for doing this, and sorry about the slow review.

I agree with Eric's remark that we should drop the lemmas that do not apply to the `compr₂` versions as these can all be proved as `hg.comp hf`.

However the `compr₂` versions are definitely useful and we should add them.

I think this will be easy to merge quickly after adjust for these suggestions.

Thanks for doing this, and sorry about the slow review.

I agree with Eric's remark that we should drop the lemmas that do not apply to the `compr₂` versions as these can all be proved as `hg.comp hf`.

However the `compr₂` versions are definitely useful and we should add them.

I think this will be easy to merge quickly after adjust for these suggestions.
I find it a little strange to talk about "injectivity" of a bilinear map in only its first argument. Could you add a sentence or two to the PR description explaining why this is interesting to you?
Is there a reason why you have formulated it as `lcomp _ _ f g` and not `g ∘ₗ f`?

That's a good point, I was just copying the nearby theorems. I realized that it makes more sense to make one for `∘ₗ` rather than for `lcomp` and `llcomp` especially since they can be rewritten in terms of `∘ₗ`, so I removed those two and added a revised one.
Can you reference the plain function version in the docstring?
Added!
Isn't the proof just `exact hf.comp hg` or similar?
You are right, I simplified it and did the same for the semilinear version.
I think every proof in this PR can be written in this way, which suggests to me that actually these lemmas aren't worth having after all.
I'm most interested in the `compr₂` versions, how would you rewrite those?

What you have is fine but we might as well golf it:
```suggestion
    (hg : Injective g) : Injective (f.compr₂ g) :=
  fun _ _ h ↦ hf <| ext fun z ↦ hg <| LinearMap.congr_fun h z
```

I think we should break this down into two lemmas as follows:
```suggestion
theorem surjective_compr₂_of_exists_rightInverse (f : M →ₗ[R] Nₗ →ₗ[R] Pₗ) (g : Pₗ →ₗ[R] Qₗ)
    (hf : Surjective f) (hg : ∃ g' : Qₗ →ₗ[R] Pₗ, g.comp g' = LinearMap.id) :
    Surjective (f.compr₂ g) := by
  intro h
  suffices ∃ m, ∀ n, g (f m n) = h n by
    obtain ⟨m, hm⟩ := this
    exact ⟨m, ext fun n ↦ by simpa using hm n⟩
  obtain ⟨g', hg'⟩ := hg
  obtain ⟨m, hm⟩ := hf (g'.comp h)
  exact ⟨m, by simp only [hm, ← comp_apply, hg', ← comp_assoc, id_comp, implies_true]⟩

/-- A version of `Function.Surjective.comp` for composition of a bilinear map with a linear map. -/
theorem surjective_compr₂_of_equiv (f : M →ₗ[R] Nₗ →ₗ[R] Pₗ) (g : Pₗ ≃ₗ[R] Qₗ) (hf : Surjective f) :
    Surjective (f.compr₂ g.toLinearMap) :=
  surjective_compr₂_of_exists_rightInverse f g.toLinearMap hf ⟨g.symm, by simp⟩
```
One benefit of this is that it makes it easy for someone to add the result that in finite dimensions `Surjective g` is enough (since this is equivalent to existence of a right inverse in finite dimensions).

Argubly we should state this in the reduced form
```suggestion
    (hg : Injective g) : Injective (fun x => g.comp (f x)) := by
```
which can also then be written for semilinear maps.
(But let's see if @ocfnash agrees)
I did some golfing here; evidently `f` is a distraction, and actually what we care about is a result about `g` alone. Could you write this lemma and put it near `injective_linearMapComp_left`?
I think I did what you wanted, but let me know if not
Yes, looks great!

```suggestion
  obtain ⟨f', hf'⟩ := hf
```

Since this one is in the linear map namespace
```suggestion
theorem surjective_comp_left_of_exists_rightInverse {σ₃₂ : R₃ →+* R₂}
```

pullRequest.title: feat(LinearAlgebra): add theorems for injective/surjective/bijective compositions of bilinear maps
